ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Representative digital X-rays from specimens prepared for experimental testing. (a) Rectangular specimens for three point bending and hardness testing. (b) A rectangular specimen for Impact Strength testing with internal porosity. (c) SENB specimens with notch and (d) a defective Brazilian specimen with a diffuse distribution of internal pores.

A macroscopic photograph of an IZOD specimen (a), and a SEM photograph of the fracture surface (b), where the tip of the origin of fracture, hackle lines, Wallner lines, and twist hackle lines can be observed (nominal magnification 20×, bar: 2mm).

A macroscopic photograph of a SENB specimen (upper photo) and a SEM photograph of the fracture surface of a SENB specimen (lower photo), where the tip of the notch can be seen. The possible origin of fracture is illustrated by two asterisks (original magnification: 190×, bar: 200μm).

A macroscopic photograph of a Brazilian specimen (inset up left), and a SEM photograph of the fracture surface of the same Brazilian specimen (a), where the Chevron notch-origin of fracture (b), Wake hackle lines at the border of pores (c, d), and hackle lines at the loading surface (e) of the specimen can be observed.
Fracture toughness mean values and standard deviations of Filtek Z-250 and Filtek Ultimate, as presented in literature [], the current study [CS], and the manufacturer [M].
Comparative demonstration of all mechanical properties for materials included in this study.
Brand name, manufacturer, lot number, resin monomer, type and percentage of filler content for materials tested.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Mean values and standard deviations (in parentheses) of Flexural Modulus (FM), Flexural Strength (FS), Brinell Hardness (HB), Impact Strength (IS), Work of Fracture (WOF) and mode II (KIIc) fracture toughness of materials tested.

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: Same superscript letters, within a column indicate no statistically significant differences (p>0.05).

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: Same superscript letters show mean values of different composite resins with no statistically significant differences (p>0.05), and same superscript numbers show mean values of different fracture toughness test with no statistically significant differences (p>0.05).

head.ce:title: Mechanical properties of contemporary composite resins and their interrelations

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Operative Dentistry, School of Dentistry, University of Athens, Greece

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Department of Operative Dentistry, School of Dentistry, University of Athens

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Dental and Biomaterial Res. Gr. Dental School, “Charite” Medical University of Berlin

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Department of Biomaterials, School of Dentistry, University of Athens

ce:correspondence.ce:text: Corresponding author at: Department of Biomaterials, School of Dentistry, University of Athens, Thivon 2, Goudi 11527, Athens, Greece. Tel.: +30 2107461102; fax: +30 2107461306.

ce:abstract.ce:abstract-sec: Objective jTo characterize a spectrum of mechanical properties of four representative types of modern dental resin composites and to investigate possible interrelations.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Four composite resins were used, a microhybrid (Filtek Z-250), a nanofill (Filtek Ultimate), a nanohybrid (Majesty Posterior) and an ormocer (Admira). The mechanical properties investigated were Flexural Modulus and Flexural Strength (three point bending), Brinell Hardness, Impact Strength, mode I and mode II fracture toughness employing SENB and Brazilian tests and Work of Fracture. Fractographic analysis was carried out in an SEM to determine the origin of fracture for specimens subjected to SENB, Brazilian and Impact Strength testing. The results were statistically analyzed employing ANOVA and Tukey post hoc test (a=0.05) while Pearson correlation was applied among the mechanical properties.

Significant differences were found between the mechanical properties of materials tested apart from mode I fracture toughness measured by Brazilian test. The latter significantly underestimated the mode I fracture toughness due to analytical limitations and thus its validity is questionable. Fractography revealed that the origin of fracture is located at notches for fracture toughness tests and contact surface with pendulum for Impact Strength testing. Pearson analysis illustrated a strong correlation between modulus of elasticity and hardness (r=0.87) and a weak negative correlation between Work of Fracture and Flexural Modulus (r=−0.46) and Work of Fracture and Hardness (r=−0.44). Weak correlations were also allocated between Flexural Modulus and Flexural Strength (r=0.40), Flexural Strength and Hardness (r=0.39), and Impact Strength and Hardness (r=0.40).
Since the four types of dental resin composite tested exhibited large differences among their mechanical properties differences in their clinical performance is also anticipated.

ce:section.ce:para: Dental composite resins are increasingly used worldwide in dental restorations. Despite the intense research on their properties and their evolution, bulk fracture and chipping is now the most common cause of failure in posterior composite resin restorations [1–4]. The fracture initiates from superficial or subsurface cracks, micropores or minor imperfections of the material, leading to the formation of a critical crack [5,6]. Although none of the mechanical properties can be used to predict the clinical performance of a given material certain properties are considered more important and indicative over others. Combining long term clinical longevity data and in vitro experimental results Ferracane 2013 [4] proposed fracture toughness and Flexural Strength as the most strongly correlated mechanical properties to the clinical performance of dental resin composite restoration. Also, in the same paper was highlighted that fracture is now the prevalent cause of clinical failure of composite resins. This approach is documented by the fact that all restorations include internal flaws and thus fracture toughness may be the most important mechanical property reflecting the resistance to intraoral fracture. The fracture toughness (KIc) represents the critical plane strain stress intensity factor [5,6]. The subscript I stands for mode I or tensile opening of the crack, the subscript II for shear and III for tear opening. For brittle materials, KIc is considered as a sufficient description [7] and thus the vast majority of previous studies on dental composites have focused on KIc. However, intraoral loading causes multi-axial stress composite in dental restorations and thus mode II and mode III fracture toughness might serve the same purpose.

The relationship of mechanical properties with intraoral performance has been extensively studied and a few significant correlations have been identified. Tyas (1990) [8] found a significant inverse correlation between surface chipping/bulk fracture of composites and fracture toughness, modulus of elasticity, and diametral tensile strength while Ferracane et al., 1999 [9] found a similar correlation between fracture toughness and marginal breakdown of composite resins. Ferracane and Condon 1999 [9] studying microfill, minifill and midfill composites, with the use of a wear simulator, showed an excellent inverse correlation between marginal breakdown and fracture toughness. Ferracane et al., 1997 [10] also reported a strong inverse correlation between wear and fracture toughness, and wear and Flexural Strength and a weaker inverse correlation between wear and hardness. In addition, fracture toughness along with Flexural Strength and Flexural Modulus has been proposed as predictors of clinical wear of composite resin restorations [11,12]. Therefore all these mechanical properties can be considered of imperative importance in composite resin characterization, in terms of their clinical performance.

Another important aspect of determining mechanical properties is the correlation among materials parameters of dental composites [13]. Although mechanical properties are considered independent (as define a different aspect of material behavior), these correlations if characterized as universal could give a quicker and simpler way to determine the material properties based on the identification of one parameter; then the unknown properties can be calculated based on the correlations [13]. A simple example is the correlation between Hardness and Elastic Modulus which has been readily used to estimate the Modulus of dental composite resins from a simple hardness measurement [13]. In mechanics there are even mathematical relationship between specific mechanical properties (i.e. Hardness=3 Yield Strength) independently of the materials tested but mostly these formulas must be further corrected, compensating for material imperfections and limitations of experimental setups [14]. Although the full spectrum of mechanical properties of composite resins has been determined in the past, the comparison among the results of different studies was hindered by the differences in materials tested and/or experimental parameters in different research setups. For instance Flexural Strength tends to increase when higher crosshead speed is applied [15]. Therefore the possible correlations were squeezed to a limited number of properties.

Recently, the composite resins have undergone a significant evolution, considering their composition, which mainly relates to the fillers and less to the monomers [16–18]. Therefore, a variety of composite resins, categorized as microhybrid, nanohybrid, nanofilled and ormocers, with significant differences in their matrix and filler composition properties, have been introduced during the last decade [19–25].

This study aims in first place to characterize a range of mechanical properties of four representative types of modern dental resin composites. Furthermore, since the clinical failure is a multi-factorial result of several types of mechanical degradations (fatigue, wear, fracture, etc.) this study also focuses on the possible interrelations among mechanical properties of the tested resin composites. The null hypothesis is that the there are not significant differences in the mechanical properties among the dental composite resins tested.

In this study, four composite resins were used, a microhybrid, a nanofil, an ormocer and a nanohybrid, as presented in Table 1. Seven mechanical properties have been determined including Flexural Modulus (FM), Flexural Strength (FS), Brinell Hardness (HB), Impact Strength (IS), mode I and mode II fracture toughness and Work of Fracture (WOF). The mode I fracture toughness (KIc) was calculated by two tests, the single edge notched bending (SENB), and the Chevron notched diametral compression test (Brazilian).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Specimen handling, X-ray testing for internal porosity and storage before testing
ce:section.ce:para: All specimens were handled with the same procedure. After removal from the mold, thin fins of composite at the edges were removed with the use of a sharp blade. The specimen dimensions were measured with a micrometer to the closest 0.01mm. All specimens were checked for internal porosity radiographically with a dental X-ray unit (Orix 70, Ardet, Milano, Italy) operating at 70kV, 5mA, and 0.35s exposure time. Digital images were collected from all specimens and the presence of internal porosity was checked by naked eye. All specimens with internal porosity (Fig. 1) were rejected and replaced by new ones and rechecked with X-rays. Then the specimens were stored in distilled water at 37±1°C for 24h prior to testing.

Flexural Modulus (FM) and Flexural Strength (FS) were determined by means of a three point bending test. Ten (10) rectangular specimens with 25mm length, 2mm width, and 2mm depth, were fabricated for each composite resin. A teflon mold was placed over a celluloid film, followed by a glass slide, and filled with composite resin and a second celluloid film, followed by a glass slide, were placed over the mold. A custom made device was used to press the glass slide over the mold for 5s in order to remove the excess of resin composite and minimize the internal porosity. The glass slab was removed and the composite resin was polymerized with five slightly overlapping irradiations (40s each) from both sides. A LED light curing unit (Radii plus, SDI, Victoria, Australia) was used with an irradiance of 950mW/cm2 measured by a radiometer (Model 100, Demetron Research Corp., Danbury, CT). After polymerization, excess composite resin was carefully removed, and the specimens were polished with SiC abrasive paper up to 800grit under water cooling in a grinding polishing machine (Ecomet III, Buehler, Lake Bluff, IL, USA). All specimens were found free of pores after X-ray testing (Fig. 1a). Then the specimens were loaded up to fracture in three-point bending employing a universal tensile testing machine (Tensometer 10, Monsanto, Swindon, UK) at rate of 0.5mm/min. The Flexural Modulus (FE) was determined by the formula:FE=L3 ΔP4bh3 Δdwhere L the span between supporting rods (20mm), h the height and b the width of the specimen, ΔP and Δd stands for the load and deflection increment, respectively, between 2 specific points in the elastic portion of the curves. The Flexural Strength was determined by the formula:FS=3FL2bh2where F is the load at fracture.

ce:section.ce:section:
2.3Brinell Hardness test n
Ten (10) rectangular specimens with 25mm length, 2mm width, and 2mm depth, were prepared for each composite resin as described above. Brinell Hardness determination was performed with a 1mm diameter indenter employing 20kg (196N) load and a 15s contact time (Diatronic 2Rc, Wolpert, Ludwigshafen, Germany). The diameter of the indentation was measured and Brinell Hardness was calculated from the formula:HB=2FπD(D−D2−d2)where F is the load applied, d the diameter of the indentation and D the diameter of the indenter. Three indentations were created per specimen and the average value was calculated to characterize the specimen hardness.

ce:section.ce:para: IS was estimated by the impact IZOD test according to a modified ASTM specification D 256-00 [26]. Ten (10) unnotched rectangular specimens (l=15mm, h=10 and b=2mm) were fabricated with the use of a brass two-piece split mold. The placement of the composite paste into the mold and polymerization was performed as described for the three point bending test. After polymerization, excess composite resin was carefully removed. Three specimens were replaced by new ones discarded due to the presence of internal porosity (Fig. 1b) and subjected to impact testing with the use of a Dynsta Dys-e 1/11 (Feinmechanik, Engelsdorf, Germany) bench IZOD impact apparatus with a swinging pendulum with 0.5J maximum energy. IS was expressed as energy per unit and calculated employing the formula:IS=Ehbwhere E is the absorbed energy calculated as the difference between the nominal (0.5J) and dynamic energy of pendulum after specimen fracture.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Single edge notched bending fracture toughness test (SENB)
ce:section.ce:para: For the SENB test, ten (10) rectangular specimens with length l=25mm, width b=2.5mm and height h=5mm depth, containing an α=2.5mm notch in the center, were fabricated per composite resin and then, subjected to three-point bending according to ASTM Standard [27]. A multiple component split Teflon mold containing a razor blade insert was used in order to produce sharp notches during curing the composite. The specimens were prepared and polymerized as described above. All specimens were found free of pores after X-ray testing (Fig. 1c). A three-point bending jig was used, with two 2mm diameter styluses and span 20mm. Specimens were loaded in the aforementioned universal testing machine at a rate of 0.5mm/min. Fracture toughness was calculated based on the following equation:KIc=3a/h1.99−(a/h)(1−(a/h))(2.15−3.93(a/h)+2.7(a/h)2PL2bh3(1+2(a/h))(1−(a/h))3where P is the load at fracture, L the distance between the two support styluses, α the notch length, h the height and b the width of the specimen. The Work of Fracture was also calculated employing the formula [28]:WOF=U2b(h−a)The term U stands for the total work found by calculating the area under the load–displacement curve.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Chevron notched diametral compression fracture toughness test (Brazilian)
ce:section.ce:para: For the Brazilian test, twenty (20) disk-shaped specimens per composite resin with 25mm diameter, 2mm thick and a chevron notch in the center of the specimen were fabricated, based on the study performed by Scherrer et al. [29] and Watanabe et al. [25]. A Teflon mold with a cylindrical hole in the center was used. The specimens were irradiated as described above but employing eleven slightly overlapping irradiations and after X-ray testing five specimens with a random distribution of internal pores were discarded (Fig. 1d) and replaced by new ones. A chevron notch was cut into the center of each specimen using a 20mm diameter and 0.6mm thick metal cutting disk. A custom apparatus was used to align and guide the cutting disk during operation. Then the specimens were loaded up to fracture in a diametral compression mode at a rate of 0.5mm/min employing the aforementioned universal tensile testing device. The specimens were stabilized on the compression jig and the inclination of the notch was aligned at θ=0° degrees (parallel to the loading direction) for mode I fracture toughness measurement (n=10), and at an angle θ=30° to the loading direction for mode II loading (n=10). Mode I and II fracture toughness was calculated using the following mathematical formulas [29]:KIc=NIPaRbπKIIc=NIIPaRbπwhere P is the fracture load applied in compression, R the disk radius, b the disk thickness, α half the crack length and NI and NII are dimensionless coefficients that are function of the relative notch size (α/R) and the inclination θ of the notch toward the plane of loading, which has been calculated by Atkinson et al. [30]:NI=A1+A212aR2NII=B1+B212αR22 sin 2θA1=1−4(sin θ)2 and A2=8(sin θ)2[1−4(sin θ)2]B1=1 and B2=−5+8(sin θ)2When inclination θ, of the notch toward the plane of loading, is set to 0° degrees represents a pure mode I and 30° a pure mode II loading respectively.

After examination under a stereoscopic microscope selective specimens were examined under scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Quanta 200, FEI, Hillsboro, OR, USA). Observation in SEM was performed under low vacuum conditions (chamber pressure 1Torr), 25kV accelerating voltage and 105μA beam current employing a Large Field Detector. Qualitative examination of the fracture surfaces was performed and secondary electron images were taken from characteristic fracture patterns (i.e. origin of fracture, hackle zone, twist hackle, etc.)

FS, FS, HB, IS, KIIc and WOF were evaluated by one-way analysis of variance (one-way Anova), followed by Tukey post hoc test (α=0.05). KIc data were statistically analyzed by two-way analysis of variance (two-way Anova), employing testing methodology (SENB and Brazilian) and material as discriminating variables. Differences among groups were allocated using Tukey post hoc test (α=0.05). Correlations among all properties were tested employing Pearson correlation.

The results of FM, FS, HB, IS, WOF and KIIc are illustrated in Table 2. The composite resin Majesty Posterior exhibited the statistically significant highest FM and HB, Admira the lowest while no differences were revealed between Filtek Z-250 and Filtek Ultimate which presented intermediate hardness values. The material Filtek Z-250 presented the statistically significant highest Flexural Strength, Admira the lowest, while no differences were found between Filtek Ultimate and Majesty Posterior. Composite resin Admira demonstrated statistically significant lower IS values compared to the rest composites and the same is true for Majesty Posterior for WOF values. Filtek Z 250 demonstrated the highest KIIc value while the Admira the lowest.

A fractured IZOD impact specimen, as well as a representative fractographic image, is illustrated in Fig. 2. The origin of the fracture, the characteristic hackle, the Wallner lines and twist hackle region are readily recognized.

The results of mode I fracture toughness (KIc) as recorded by the SENB and Brazilian technique, are presented in Table 3. Two-way ANOVA showed no significant interaction (p=0.116) between material and techniques. Statistically significant differences were identified among the two experimental techniques used for the fracture toughness measurement (p<0.001), as well as among the four composite resins (p<0.001). Statistically significant lower fracture toughness KIc values were recorded for all the composite resins measured by Brazilian technique compared with the SENB test (p<0.001). According to the SENB technique, composite resin Admira demonstrated statistically significant lower fracture toughness values compared to the rest composites (p=0.018). No differences were detected among any pair of composites when the Brazilian test was employed.

Fig. 3 demonstrates the fracture surface and the notch of a specimen loaded under SENB testing. The end of notch is readily distinguished from the fracture surface while the possible origin of fracture is located ahead of the notch (indicated by two asterisks is identified on the image).

A fractured Brazilian specimen, as well as a representative fractographic image, is illustrated in Fig. 4. The origin of the fracture could be readily recognized (Fig. 4b), due to the presence of wake hackle lines, beginning at the border of pores (Fig. 4c, d) inside the composite specimen toward the path of fracture. Characteristic hackle lines could be observed at the loading surface (Fig. 4e), implying a secondary fracture initiating from the loading surface of the specimen.

Pearson correlation coefficients (r) among the mechanical properties tested are presented in Table 4 along with the respective p values. A strong correlation was identified between FM and HB (r=0.87) while weak correlations were also found between other properties.

According to the results of this study the null hypothesis is rejected for the mechanical properties tested with the exception of the Brazilian KIc. The materials tested were deliberately chosen as representative types of modern dental composite resins classified as microhybrid, nanohybrid, nanofilled and ormocers and they are recommended by their manufactures for posterior restorations. Generally, the results indicate that the mechanical behavior of four different types of composite tested is varied significantly among each others anticipating differences in their clinical behavior.

Flexural Modulus for Z-250 was found similar to the manufacturer data (11.0GPa) and Ilie and Hickel (10.3±0.6GPa) [20] results. However lower values (8.5GPa [31] and 7.6±1.3GPa [22]) have been reported by other investigators. Filtek Ultimate showed identical values with the manufacturer data (12.0GPa) while the results of Admira are in full accordance with previously reported results (7.9±3.5GPa) [20]. The Flexural Strength of Filtek Z-250 is in accordance to the previous studies [20,22,23,31,32] and the same is true for Filtek Ultimate [23] and Admira [20,21,33]. Despite the fact that the Brinell Hardness data cannot be directly compared with others Hardness scale (such as Vickers and Knoop) it is interesting that the current Brinell ranking of the materials tested fully matches with the ranking of previous studies [21,24,34]. This ranking follows the decreasing order of filler volume percentage of materials tested reflecting the effect of filler volume percentage on the mechanical properties of dental composite resins.

Fractographic analysis of specimens after impact testing verified that the origin of fracture was located as it is expected at the contact surface of pendulum with specimen for all materials tested (Fig. 2). Although IS can reflect the mechanical energy required to cause fracture in a restoration such as trauma under shock loading, IS in not considered as an intrinsic property as it is influenced by testing parameters and specimen geometry [28] and thus it is scarcely referred in dental literature for dental composites. However, the results of this study are close to values found in a previous research study when unnotched specimens were tested [26].

Contrary to the aforementioned skepticism for IS the fracture toughness is an intrinsic property of the materials and thus has been thoroughly studied for dental resin composites through different experimental techniques such as the SENB [22,31,35,36], the compact tension specimen [23,35], the short-rod [37] and mini-rod [35,38] fracture toughness tests, the double torsion [35,39,40] and the Chevron notched Brazilian disk test [25,29,41], which can also estimate mode II fracture toughness. However the fracture toughness values presented in the literature, demonstrate a large dispersion, due to the use of different tests, as well as due to the diversity of the characteristics of the notch or crack created in the specimens of the various tests [22,23,25,29,41,42]. Nevertheless, fracture toughness is an intrinsic property of a certain material and therefore, different experimental studies of the same material should provide values without statistically significant differences. In this study SENB test was selected due to its popularity in dental literature and also because it can provide WOF values. Brazilian is an experimental setup capable of determining both the KIc and KIIc values.

As expected two-way ANOVA showed no significant interaction between techniques and materials tested implying that each factor exerts an independent effect on the measured values. Fig. 5a depicts the fracture toughness values found in the present study as well as values reported in the literature for Filtek Z-250. It is readily shown that the value of fracture toughness of the current study are in accordance with the results of two previous studies [22,36] and the manufacturer data. Higher [43] and lower values [31] should be attributed to the violation of width height and span relationship as has been implemented by ASTM E399-08. According to this, specimen height should be twice the thickness and supporting span should be 4 times the height. Another source of variation might be attributed to the notch preparation employing a cutting disk. The values of Brazilian testing are in accordance to previously reported value by Watanabe et al. [25]. Similarly Fig. 5b illustrates the results of fracture toughness found in literature for Filtek Ultimate. However it should be noted that only Shah et al. [23] have reported fracture toughness values of Filtek Ultimate while the rest fracture toughness values refer to Filtek Supreme, the predecessor of Filtek Ultimate, which shares the same resin matrix and filler with Filtek Ultimate, according to 3M/ESPE, has the same weight percentage filler but slightly less volume percentage filler (59.5%). The fracture toughness values derived from SENB technique from the present study and as reported by Yap et al. [36], Rodrigues et al. [22], and the manufacturing company (3M-ESPE), seem to be comparable apart from Lien and Vanderwalle [31] for the reason mentioned above. Again Brazilian KIc showed significantly lower values but in full accordance with the results of previously reported study [25]. At the best of our knowledge, there are no fracture toughness values for the rest of the materials, apart from the 1.58±0.31 MPa m for Admira measured with SENB [43]. The fracture toughness values derived from the compact tension specimen technique as reported by Shah et al. [23] for both materials are slightly lower to SENB.

Based on the comparison of fracture toughness data as presented in Fig. 5 a few general comments might be drawn regarding the comparison among experimental techniques. Mode I fracture toughness values estimated by the Brazilian test in the present study, as well as in the study of Watanabe et al. [25] exhibited values about 50% lower than the ones derived from the SENB method for the same materials [36]. Scherrer et al. [29] also reported the same trend for composite resins intended for indirect restorations. Their fracture toughness values were calculated with the use of precracked Brazilian test, and were found to be about 50% lower than the ones estimated from SENB technique for the same materials [44]. The Brazilian test has been proposed as the indicated method for calculation of rock fracture toughness from the International society for rock mechanics [45] and a different mathematical formula is used. Rock fracture toughness is considered valid when a higher ratio of specimen width to diameter is used than that used in the present study and in previous studies in dental literature [25,29,41]. This might also explain the outcome of fractographic analysis where crack initiates from the edge of the notch as well as from the loading periphery of the specimens. Nevertheless, the mathematical formula for the calculation of fracture toughness has been also criticized for its validity and it also considered a reason for the lower values obtained by Brazilian testing.

Mode II Brazilian KIIc values were found almost double the mode I values estimated by the same method a finding which is in full accordance with previous data [25,29]. WOF is defined as the value of energy consumed to produced two fractured surfaces and it is correlated to materials resistance against crack propagation [46]. WOF shares the same units with IS as it is given in energy per unit surface (kJ/m2). The lower WOF should be attributed to the available time for subcritical crack growth during testing [15], the presence of notch and finally the fact that under impact testing the fracture has a bigger effective surface area (Fig. 2) absorbing higher energy during breakage.

A comparative demonstration of all properties tested is presented in Fig. 6. The most heavily (82vol%) filler loaded Majesty Posterior showed increased Modulus following the trend of increased Modulus with increasing filler volume [47] but intermediate values for fracture toughness supporting the findings that fracture toughness starts declining in fillers percentage above 60% [43]. Contrary Filtek Z-250 (60.0vol%) and Filtek Ultimate (63.3vol%) demonstrate the higher fracture toughness despite their lower values of Modulus and Hardness compared to Majesty Posterior. Although direct clinical implications can hardly been drawn based on the aforementioned mechanical properties it might be proposed that Admira should not be used in stress bearing areas.

Only FM and BH showed a strong correlation (r=0.87) a finding which is in full accordance with previously reported high correlation between Knoop hardness and modulus of elasticity [13]. Medium to weak correlation were also identified between IS and BH (r=0.40), FM and FS (r=0.40), and FS and BH (0.39). The weak correlation between FM and FS has been also reported previously (r=0.5) [20] while a weak correlation was found between BH and FS despite the previously mentioned strong correlation (r2=0.90) between Diametral tensile strength and Vickers hardness [48] a finding that might be appended to the compression nature of diametral testing [49]. A weak but negative correlation was found between WOF and both FM (r=−0.46) and HB (r=−0.44) verifying the general rule that the increase in mechanical strength (i.e. Hardness, modulus of elasticity, Fracture strength, etc.) with increasing filler content is achieved at the expense of plasticity decreasing the matrix ability to absorb energy through plastic deformation ahead of the crack tip. In the present study, no correlation was revealed between SENB fracture toughness and the tested mechanical properties. This finding might be appended to the fact that the mechanism of crack propagation in composite resins does not depend only on the elastic–plastic behavior, but also on the polymer matrix composition, the interaction of the polymer matrix with the fillers and the other mechanical properties. Although correlation was also found between mode I and mode II fracture toughness measured by Brazilian test these correlations will not be further discussed due to the aforementioned comments regarding the validity of the numerical outcome.

The contribution of this study in the field is that there are not strong correlations between the mechanical properties of different types of composite resins other than between Hardness and Modulus. Since the materials tested exhibited large differences in their mechanical properties and based on the aforementioned correlations of mechanical properties with intraoral aging, a dissimilar clinical performance is anticipated for the materials tested.

ce:list-item.ce:para: The different type of dental resin composite tested demonstrated significant differences in their mechanical properties.
A strong correlation was found only between hardness and Flexural Modulus.

Brazilian test seems to significantly underestimate the fracture toughness values and thus the validity of this method for the evaluation of fracture toughness of dental resin composites is questionable.
